Got into the closed beta for my dedication to the series, and was not disappointed at all. China could use a little buff considering the fact that the game is called Red Dragon after all, and half of China's within time frame units have been questionably ommitted. Naval warfare could use a little tweaking as well, because its implementation was poor at first. However the upcoming naval patch notes look extremely promising.

In terms of improvement over the AirlandBattle, this game has done it all. Land battles are now far more realistic, intense, and tactical thanks to some of the revolutionary changes that Eugen has made in map design, pace, and terrain. Indeed, this game has taken the openness and unlimited tactical/strategic opportunities that were the trademark of W:EE, and combined them with the ferocity that was characteristic of W:AB battles.

But overall, from my many hours of closed beta testing, this is the ultimate culmination of the awesome Wargame series. The enormous scale, realistic terrain, and the unlimited tactical, operational and even strategic options that this glorious game provides has never ceased to amaze me. Indeed, this is any amateur wargamer's/armchair general's (like myself) wet dream, and I would fully recommend this to anyone seeking an immersive, immense, and ultimately fulfilling historical/military experience.

One of the best strategy titles ever released. An otherwise perfect game dragged down It's by subpar naval and horrible community. The Wargame series is unique in that it takes away some of the more tedious aspects of RTS games such as base building and resource gathering, but still manages to be more complex and harder to play than most RTS titles.

The scale of this game can be truly staggering, even for veteran players. Even the smallest of maps will divide your forces between two or three fronts, and having a good unit composition (which is key to winning any RTS game) requires combining a lot of different unit types to support each other. You won't be able to win by simply spamming one or even a few types of units. Positioning and logistics are key, even the heaviest armored tank will die like a ♥♥♥♥♥ if hit from the rear and It doesn't really matter how powerful your units' weapons are if they're out of ammo and panicked.

Another feature that sets Wargame apart is the deck building. You're spoiled for choice when it comes to units. With over 1500 units between 17 countries and 7 deck types, you're bound to go up against a bunch of really interesting armies while playing. Objectively weaker nations are given more unit availability, ensuring they stay viable and each nation has their own unique playstyle; UK being the slow moving juggernaut while nations like France hit hard and stay mobile. reviewText:
For prospective buyers, here's what you need to know:

Pros
The game features a great number of nationalities, etc that are rarely (if ever) included in games with this sort of setting. Countries such as France, Canada, Norway, Poland, Czechoslovakia, and North Korea are fully playable with their own pallet of men and material to work with. The introduction of the Coalition deck type, which allows you to build your own army of units drawing from a pool of two or more countries, allows nations deemed to be 'minor' to join forces and in many cases become more relevant than the period giants of the United States and the Soviet Union.

Red Dragon maintains the playable nations and features of the previous titles. The setting being moved to Asia really just means they've added new nations, and the maps available for multiplayer have shifted to that setting, as well as a time line bump into 1991 for non-prototype units.

The units are acceptably rendered. Save for some model and texture nitpicks for grognards and military enthusiasts (ERA tiles in the wrong place, etc) the graphics are overall pleasant.

While the ranges of weapon systems represented in the game are by no means realistic, they are still measured in thousands of meters.

If you liked World in Conflict, this is the closest thing to a spiritual sequel you will have access to.
Cons
You may notice that in the above, I didn't mention the much-advertised naval component. Roughly 50% of this game's seling point, the naval game is completely botched. It's a sloppy mess with no direction, where the prime strategy is to huddle up your ships and pray that their combined CIWS can shoot down incoming missiles. There is no witty maneuvering involved. In multiplayer games, few players bother with the naval maps. And whose who do find an imbalanced implimentation where ComBlock ships objectively trounce NATO vessels every time due to more powerful anti-shipping missiles and better CIWS scores. Eugen is supposedly going to address these issues, but it has been over half a year.

Multiplayer community is measured in the hundreds, rather than the thousands one might expect from other genres. RTS games tend to struggle if it's not Starcraft or Company of Heroes. Because the game has boiled down to its hardcore online community, public games tend to be with people who are extremely experienced with the mechanics that will obliterate a new player without the new player having a chance to learn anything. This is definately a game to play with friends, unless you're an RTS pro or a masochist.

Modding support is on the low end of the spectrum. Modders can edit unit code and behavior, but there will be no mapping.

Previous titles in the franchise, I feel, had better maps.
Overall
I would recommend this game to anyone who has a passion for this era in history and 'what if' scenarios. There is an upcoming (free) DLC worth of content which may or may not address some of the cons I pointed out above. The relative scale of the game is something we don't get to see very often and promises a unique experience. Because the developers are planning to move on to a different franchise after development for Red Dragon ends, there is no fear of this game becoming 'obsolete' in a matter of months.

reviewText:
Outstanding quality RTS that any military nut would enjoy.  Will also stress out your grey matter, too.  If you aren't familiar with the Wargame series, it's a borderline strategic simulator more than an RTS. No base building, no real resources (besides point income from holding sectors), and every unit has morale, health, ammo, and fuel that needs to be tended to carefully with supply lines.

The scale is unlike what most other games in the genre offer.  It reminds me almost of the original Supreme Commander in terms of sher volume of units on the field and map size.  Every unit you take into battle will never come back alive once destroyed, and you need to make your own decks of units to take into battle, which is almost a kind of game in itself...finding the right unit combos or roles to take.  One of the major reasons I recommend this game is because of that.

The army variety and unit selection is also awe inspiring.  You can pick from about 1,500 units, all modeled correctly to their real counterpart and act like the real one too.  Nations to build from include the US, Canada, France, UK, Germany, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Poland, Russia, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, China, and Best Korea (I mean North Korea).  There's an army for everyone's taste and they all feel and play unique.

Naval battles need some work and balancing, though, but it also may be just the nature of modern warfare on the ocean.  It revolves around who makes the biggest ship blob and has the best radar gattling gun screen to stop incomming cruise missiles.

Overall if you wanna work your brain a little in an RTS and focus entirely on the war and not the bases/economy, this is the thing for you.

It's a bit late for a proper review but why not.

Overview
If you know the series, Red Dragon doesn't really change much. Take ALB and add a few more countries and more units. A few more maps. A dubious artillery buff, to say the least. And there you go.

If you don't know the series, well... Get it now. Especially if you are even remotely interested in military or real time strategy.

Specifics
The main thing that Red Dragon purports to innovate from the previous series iterations is naval combat. It's a great idea on paper but of difficult execution, and unfortunately Eugen didn't pull it off. The ideas of amphibious invasions, maritme support, and even straight out naval battle are all exciting. But somehow it doesn't deliver. The scale is wrong, the balance is off, the tactics are not right, and the naval gameplay is down right terrible. You won't even find multiplayer games for naval battles. On the positive side, it is a somewhat cool novelty for the single player campaign -- with the caveat that if you are focusing on the campaign you are missing out in what makes this game great: Multiplayer.

The one cool innovation though is amphibious units in a small scale. You're able to cross rivers with APCs and such. That's applicable to many maps and it does change the gameplay, giving access to more areas of the map and changing the dynamics around bridges and water. Unfortunately, don't expect to run water-dedicated units.

The maps are improved. There are a few new ones of course, and in general they are more varied. They have a more rugged terrain which is better than ALBs and much better than EE's flatlands, Where there are larger hills in RD they are more accessible, especially for infantry. reviewText:
I would have to classify Wargame as my favorite RTS of all time. Here is my rundown of the game.

You will like this game if you enjoy battles that depend upon knowledge, tactics, and force composition for victory. You will enjoy this game if you dont like base building or economy management in an rts and prefer to focus on gaining territory and destroying enemy units. You will enjoy this game if you like a mostly realistic approach to war, including logistical supply lines, reconnaisance, artillery, and aerial attack that are lacking or understated in most rts games.

You will not like this game if you feel base building and economy are essential to rts games. You will not like this game if you want a simple rts. You will not like this game if you like micromanagement of units and twitchy gameplay like in a starcraft game.

Now here are some need to know things. The game's tutorial sucks. Go watch some youtube tutorials and gameplay videos to learn better. 1-2 games watched should be enough to learn the basics of how to play. That leads into the second thing. Mastering this will take time, and the learning curve is steep for 2 reasons. Knowledge of the differences in the units in this game is critical to long term success, and identifying whether the T72 variant shooting at you is a 50 point cheap tank or a 150 point expensive tank is very important. This means that learning what all the different stats for each weapon type mean is important to know the capabilities of a given friendly or enemy unit, and then to know what capabilities of the hundreds of units in the game have based on that. This isnt extremely complicated, as there are several weapon types even if the individual weapons are different damage values, but it is time consuming to learn and memorize this.

This is the steep learning curve mentioned in several reviews for this game. But what it does mean is that those who persevere through early losses as they familiarize themselves with the game are rewarded with a deep and satisfying strategy title that emphasizes combat itself and knowledge of the enemy to gain victory.

Now lets get to deck building. As there is no base building or economy to speak of in the game, you army is determined before you enter battle, when you build a deck. Every army has a certain amount of points it have total and every unit you put in the deck counts against that point total. It is important to look at unit composition and strategy at this point, but dont worry - even veteran wargame players routinely adjust their deck compositions for maximum effectiveness, and you should expect no less as a newbie. The deck builder is where you go to look at the stats for all the units and it really helps out with learning the game before and after a match to look up a unit that did well against you to see why it did well.

Last but not least, visit the eugen forums and also ask players in the chat for advice. There are trolls, true, but there are also people who will help out with any questions you have despite how stupidly childish and amusing the chat may seem (i enjoy just watching the chat sometimes, its really funny).


Overall, I give the game a 10/10 because I have never played an rts this much, or liked one this much, since command and conquer generals and the first starcraft. And now I cant go back to those because this is so much better.

reviewText:
A very challenging and rewarding RTS. This is probably one of the best RTS' ever made. It has definitely been one of my favourite gaming experiences of all time.

The Good
+ Multiplayer is fun, and good enough to keep things competitive (there has been a laudable level of commitement by the developers to keep the game balanced, although the general sense is that it isn't perfect but pretty darn close).
+ Build 'decks' from over 1500 different units, based on real-world models.
+ Use real-world tactics to win! Feigned retreats, ambushes, combined offensives - this is absolutely awesome!
+ The dev has brought out several free DLC's adding new units, coalitions, and maps.

The Bad
- Naval combat was a real selling point for this game originally, but it was never well regarded by the community and has been practically abandoned.
- The AI is pretty stupid in skirmishes, but multiplayer is where you want to be anyway.

The Ugly
~ The learning curve is steep, but definitely worth it! (check out SandyGunfox's 200-page guide to Wargame before you even load the game)
~ You'll want to find people to communicate and play with - if you're going solo with random teams you will get railed every single time!
~ I haven't played the campaign...

The End?

Ahh where to begin. Well, this certainly isn't your average RTS. Far from it in fact. This is frankly the kind of strategy game I've been hoping to see for over ten years. Now, I have heard some say that you really need to be a military or cold war history enthusiast in order to appreciate Wargame. I may be biased as I have studied military weapon systems since I was a little kid, but I have to disagree. From the standpoint of an RTS game, I believe it is unmatched and I will give some reasons why.

It’s actually a bit difficult to compare to other games... see with many RTS games you're building your base, having little skirmishes toward the beginning to gain unit experience, with the ultimate goal of massing units for a big push. With Wargame, there is no base building... it is all actual military maneuvers, weapon system knowledge, use of cover and concealment both for survivability and ambush, use of recon to spot enemy units for more combat oriented units, gaining Line of Sight (LOS) prior to and maintaining it during engagements (more difficult than it sounds), use of support systems such as Artillery, AAA, and SAMs to provide cover for advancing infantry and armored units, use of special forces infantry to wreak havoc behind enemy lines, capitalizing on terrain features to enable better LOS, spreading out of units so that a single airstrike won't eliminate half your assault force... but not so thin that they cannot cover each other. At the beginning of a match, there is usually a push to gain strategic positions (which supply reinforcement points) and dig in, then using recon to find gaps in enemy defenses and pushing through, encircling the enemy and/or simply cutting off their supply routes and territories. So... Wargame really is an interesting combination, it’s slow like a chess game at times... and then in a matter of literally seconds it can turn into a massive brawl.

reviewText:
My Review for Wargame: Red Dragon

I have always been a lover for strategy games. I loved playing Empire and Napoleon Total War ( Which I highly recommend playing aswell). But there was a very limited amount of modern war type strategy games. And then I found the Wargame Series.

Gameplay:

Warning: There is a HUGE learning curve for this game. You just can't start off and know how to play well. I recommend reading the 200 page guide(By SandyGunfox) about how to play the game. I remember starting off without reading the 200 page guide and my army got streamrolled. I didn't know what to do. But after the reading the guide I got the hang of the game a bit. But just reading the 200 page guide is not enough , experience is vital for this game. Every game is different, no games are the same. You need to learn how to defend your flanks, how to assault enemy positions and other strategy's for turning the battle into your teams favour. You also need to learn the strength and weaknesses of the unit's you command on the battlefield. It also takes a LONG time to win your first game , this is because EVERYONE on the team is vital to the outcome of the battle, so expect many defeats at first, but when you get more experience and training the wins will come rolling in. Overall this game has a difficult learning curve BUT after learning to play properly the gameplay is amazing.

Gameplay Verdict: 9 / 10

Graphics:

One of the best graphics for a Real-time strategy game I've ever seen. Of course you need a good computer to run it on high settings, but even not on high settings it looks good. The tank battles and Infantry battles in towns look good too. It's also great to see an enemy heavy tank go up in flames as your Spec Ops infantry sneaks up and blows it up, or watch as an artillery barrage kills a vast amount of charging infantry.

Graphics verdict: 8 / 10

Audio:

The game sounds great! The gunshots of infantry battles in towns sound really realistic and going close up on an airplane and hearing the engine as it is getting ready to drop napalm on a load of infantry in a town is amazing!
Audio Verdict: 8 / 10

Overall:

This game barely has any flaws , except that it has a large learning curve, you just can't pick up this game and start playing. But after that the game start's getting better and better as you win more and more battles.This game is amazing and a must buy for any strategy game fan.

Final Verdict: 9 / 10

reviewText:
First of all, this is a very under rated quality game. Massive battles, wide variety of strategies and units, good single player experience (though the computer does cheat) and a multiplayer experience that deserves to be in the professional gaming leagues. This is an absolute gem of a game for any strategy game player.

One of the great aspects about the game is that it makes losing troops very difficult for me, but just like real war, sometimes you have to push your troops in order to take an objective even though you know you'll take losses. As a commander, it is your job to make those losses worth the effort.

While I am mostly praising this game, there are some big drawbacks that can potentially be patched with a hotfix.
#1 There are several hidden stats in the game. Units with silenced weapons are not clearly marked and neither are units with auto-loaders. In the forums it has been stated that there will be a stat indicating auto-loaders with a proper description if I remember right, so this is likely to be fixed in the future but I wonder if they will reveal all the hidden stats and abilities in a clear defining manor.

#2 The multiplayer community can be quite toxic. For a game that focuses on its multiplayer aspect, it is the biggest detriment to the game since you will have people who leave the game just because their initial push failed or even if they lose one unit. This often causes a cascade effect where people leave  one after another and while there are bonuses for the remaining team members and it is quite possible for the remaining members to win on their own, it often means that there are too many fronts for so few people to deal with and there is nothing that can be done. In addition to this, team killing is a potential problem. Luckily the team killing problem is rare, but when you're waiting in a lobby for a 10v10 map for about half an hour just to begin, it is quite disheartening when one of your team mates decides to bomb the spawning location killing most of the allied troops then proceed to bomb all of the supply bases and command vehicles before leaving.

#3 Artillery is very prevelant and there are few counters. This is somewhat a reality of war that I mostly don't mind in this game, but this is bad in a few ways. One of which is that it just becomes an annoyance when you're constantly getting spammed by arty even when you take little to no losses since it often isn't used properly. Another way is that you'll often have team mates on your own team that don't know how to use artillery properly, then they waste all of their supplies achieving almost nothing, and then they start taking from allied supplies which deprives front line troops with repairs, ammo, and fuel. The final way that the artillery spam is a bad thing is because people neglect to mark the locations they are sending artillery shells (or bombing runs from airplanes) and thus there becomes friendly fire issues.

My suggestion for avoiding the pit falls that somewhat plague this game is to manage to get some friends in the game that you know are reliable, or even better yet, bring friends with you to buy the game and play with you. It's the best way to play and provides a lot of enjoyment for anyone who can work together as a team.

This is quite lengthy but I've basically split it into FAQs which I see new players often ask in the game chat (this is mainly for people who have never played any of the Wargame series before instead of people coming to this from EE and ALB):


Q: Is the game hard to learn?


Yes and no. It's easy to learn how to play; it's very hard to learn how to play well (which in my opinion is where a lot of the fun lies).


Q: Is it a bit overwhelming to new players?


It was for me, and I think that can be what puts some people off this game before they've really gotten into it. The huge number of units is quite scary if you've never played any of the Wargame series before (I hadn't). Perseverance is key at the start, but once you get used to the game, you'll find this a joy rather than something to be afraid of.


Q: Should I play the tutorials first?


There are actually no playable tutorials in RD. The tutorials are basically just text with instructions on what to do. It is worth giving these a read to start with, but I appreciate that this is likely to be quite boring for some players (although if you really dislike this idea, I'm not sure if this is really the game for you).

Do not despair, however. There are plenty of people who have made Youtube vids to give you instruction not only on the mechanics of the game but also on deck-building (which is important to this game but not something you need to spend tonnes of time on if you don't want to). I can highly recommend ICBMRaptor (I love his tutorials and other Wargame vids, it's worth watching them if you're new since watching someone else play multiplayer games can be a good way of learning), Bubblebox (nice, clear explanantions of stuff), Boltsauce and VulcanHDGaming.

It was poorly delivered...



Firstly,

When the game was first announced, there was a lot of talk of naval been added, which is the biggest feature of the game aside from the fact that it now focuses on the Korean Peninsula and has the Asian nations in the fight.

Sadly during the Alpha, navel was horrible... The OPFOR (now called REDFOR) was overpowered in terms of the naval aspect of the game forcing NATO players to try to ditch naval altoghter and try to win by land. This can be seen in some of the early videos of the game during beta.

In the game current state, the naval feature is still looked down upon by players because it still involves the same way to win as it did in Alpha, although there seems to be somewhat less blobbing of the ships.  But to a beginner, he would come to think that blobbing his ships together is a good thing.

Which there is nothing wrong with that thought, because the only way or the main way your ships will be destroyed are by missiles.  They can fend off the incoming missiles using a Close-in weapon system or CIWS.  While one ship that has the CIWS can stop (at best) two missiles, a second ship will stop a third.  So following that pattern you can see why players tend to “blob” their ships.

The same thing can be said for the player who is doing the attack.  More missiles means you’ll need a better defense and if your opponent defense is not strong enough, some missiles will punch through.  Which in terms... leads to the spamming.

So, during my entire time of playing this game (which was a total of 300 hours) I can honestly say that I tried to avoid any games that involved naval, because it seemed like a stupid feature to play. So if your looking into buying this game for the naval warfare, don't because it feels like a taked on feature that doesn't introduce anything new after your first 2-4 battles. It's nothing more but who can shot more missiles at once will win...




Now my second biggest problem which is that new deck system, or the number of limitations they now have on it.  For me, that deck system ALB (Wargame: AirLand Battle) had was perfect.  Comparing it to this game it now feels like I can no longer put a specific nation to fight in various ways, because of the newly added five card limit to a section for standard deck.

This newly added limitation was strongly noticeable for me when putting together the infantry for my decks.  The first limitation I had to get over was the five card limit for a standard deck, while the second limitation I have to get over was the number of specific transports I was allowed to have for my infantry.

The second limitation was strongly noticeable when I created my decks for the SSSR. (USSR or the Soviet Union) The number of the BMP3’s I was able to use in this game was laughable compared to the number I was able to have in ALB.  Which was odd because in that game the BMP3 was a prototype but mind you, it no longer is in this game.

So oddly enough the word prototype" means you can have more according to this game.  But ignoring that and talking about the fact that they're the BMP3's only comes with one of the weakest infantry in the game. This helps illustrates that the added deck limitations makes more units useless than others and also shows something I hated most about this series. It’s that units and the things they come with aren’t very modular…


Now my last problem with the game is the community.  The number of “pub-stomps” has increased dramatically in this game to the point where you’ll see game lobbies named “randoms only”.  Your chances of coming across a game that is not a “pub-stomp” are like 1 in 10.

But here's the kicker of this problem... When players ask for help the on the forums.  Typically I’ve seen a number of responses that state

Great game.

You play as one of the many modern factions like America, Russia, China, Japan, Korea, British, Germany, etc and you build a 'deck' which is basically something you stuff with vehicles, infantry, naval units or air from that said faction or multiple factions. (Bonus to sticking to a single faction, and there is prebuilt decks for beginners)

There is land, air and naval combat. The vehicles are realistic. There is fuel, detracking, getting your rotor shot out and your copter crashing into a tank column and blowing it up. There is ways to get fuel again, because you start with a FoB (or Forward Operations Base) which supplies your troops with ammo, fuel, repairs, etc. The jets come in off-map from an air field and do what they do, and can retreat back to the air field (if they make it) for repairs and ammo restocking.

The maps are absolutely gigantic. The enviorment feels alive. You can hide your troops in the foliage, secure and use buildings, craters are left as permanent scars in maps from your wars (Just for the duration of the game, you won't go back into a map filled with craters from previous games) there are mountains, forests, plains, plateaus, rivers, lakes, oceans, you name it, it's there.

It's balanced. Yes, factions may favor one type of unit over another, like (example only, not true) USA may favor Infantry and have better infantry than the French, but the French have better air support, etc. Everything has a counter. Air has anti air and other air units like fighters and attack helicopters. Bazookas and RPGs and jets and other helicopters for ground and naval and air for other naval.

There is objectives, you get command vehicles to secure sectors in a map usually codenamed something like a military term such as Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta. The more zones you control the more advantages you get such as new ways to bring in units to that zone instead of your FoB's location.

The graphics are superb. Extremely realistic, and you can zoom in on ongoing battles and see from almost a 3rd person perspective.

I definitely recommend it whole heartedly, it's a great game extremely addicting and very fun.

9.9/10

The best real-time strategy game I have played in my life. Takes a bit of decking around to figure out what all the stats mean and how to abuse them in a nice deck, but when you beat your friend in a 1vs1 its oh so sweet. Try reading The Art of War by Sun Tzu if you're having problems, its in audiobook form. And I suggest you get some friends to play with you, the ones that roam the public multiplayer games can be very good. Whereas if you have friends that are as noob as you are, then you can win some, then they win some as they adjust their approach, then you win some because you adjusted your approach, etc. This is very rewarding gameplay.

The game is known for being as close to realism as possible, and strategically it actually is. You have to supply your troops and ships with ammo and rockets if you have a prolonged engagement (so your ships in naval battles need supply ships as a part of your deck). You also have to use infrantry in forests and buildings to spot and sneak up on the enemy (you can't shoot what you can't see, though you can shoot artillery at suspected locations).
The battles are very intriguing. You can't just rush ahead, because to win you have to kill a certain number of points worth of units, but if too many of your own units die then the enemy wins because they killed enough units before you killed enough units. This gives a very real feeling, because you have to take care of your troops as you would in real life. Each unit you get killed is another set of points for the enemy. The trick is to make each exchange worth it, so you take more points than you lose in the engagement. This is tricky, but very rewarding gameplay.

Pros: Everything, the only thing missing is a pure city map (unless I missed it). Just about every military asset in the world worth its paint is in the game, and there's endless replayability because no two engagements are the same. No base setup, no tedious setup of power-stations and resource harvesters, no tech-tree to worry about, no real unit cap that you'll ever approach (except in naval battles), there's a counter for everything if you only have the presence of mind to get it out when you need it (and managed to fit it into your deck).
Cons: It can be overwhelming, because there's so much to figure out. But this can be negated by playing with someone who begins playing at the same time as you, then you're on equal ground and will win every other match against each other as you figure things out.

reviewText:
Pretty fun game if you have an interest in larger scale military strategy, with a combined arms approach rather than just spamming your high cost tank. Alot of units have their utility, so cheaper units are not always directly inferior and have their use - aswell as cheaper units will give you more numbers. If you have for example a 180 cost tank, you will only get 1 or 2, where as a 90 point tank will give you maybe 8 or 7, allowing you to capitalize on numbers at a cost of a more powerful unit.


Not too easy to learn, so it's good to have a friend who is good at the game to teach you the ins and outs.


Alot of people complain about balance and there is a balance issue in certain places with the game. Depending on who you are, this is either a good or bad thing:  You may like a game balanced away from realism to make it slightly more 'fair', or you may prefer that the game lets both sides/individual nations have their strong and weak points.

Personally, I prefer to play against an enemy and in the lobby see what nation they are playing as, to know what their strong points and weak points are in terms of units, to help devise a plan to counteract that. I prefer to play a game where I have to think to nullify the enemies advantage, than have everything completely balanced.

At the end of the day, superior tactics will win games over just good units - Adapt and overcome. This sort of thing comes apparent when a team of 1980s North Korea beats a cocky well rounded BLU team. I've seen it happen, and no, it really isn't easy, but if you can outplan your enemy, you'll have positive kill/loss ratios in any match.


If at the end of the day you really just can't get a grip on the game but are willing to learn, theres an entire 200 page 'red dragon for dummies' guide that can teach you everything you need to know, although you really just need to in most cases think realistically about things.

reviewText:
I should have written this Wargame Red Dragon review a long time ago. Better late than never I guess. I'll compensate with kind of a mega review.

Wargame Red Dragon is definitely one of my top 3 real time strategy games of all time. (The other two being Supreme Commander and Starcraft II.) It's the third game in the series and it takes the franchise to a new level with the implementation of naval warfare, several new nations, graphical polish and rebalancing of old mechanics like artillery power. I don't think any RTS game offers the equivalent experience as Wargame and I believe every self-respecting RTS gamer should play Wargame.

Wargame series is so deep that you could sink Mount Everest into it. And it's not just the sheer amount of units and all the simulation, but the tactical opportunities.

Perhaps you should shoot smoke to cover your advance? Or would you like to do an amphibious landing behind enemy lines and cut their reinforcement route? How about sending an elite recon squad behind enemy lines to observe what kind of troops enemy is bringing in? They can also direct artillery fire on enemy supply depot and artillery battery. (Just watch out for counter-artillery) Perhaps you could open the game with an airborne assault to an important crossroads town?  Can't stop enemy advance? Try napalming the important bridges to block them and buy time.

It's amazing what kind of devious evil plans human mind can come up with. I personally really enjoy this aspect of the game. When tanks get boring you can spice things up with some crazy special forces action.

Realism is a big word in Wargame. Every one of the 1 500 different units have their individual statistics for weapons (type, ammunition, armor penetration, explosive power, fire rate, range, accuracy, stabilizer, targeting system...) armor (front, side, rear, top) and all sort of miscellaneous stuff like fuel, speed, size, stealth, countermeasures, operational range etc. They are all significant when you decide what units you call to battlefield.

However, Wargame is no Dwarf Fortress. Even my 57-year-old dad has managed to master the game. I think it's common sense you shouldn't move your tanks through a town in which you have spotted enemy special forces moving in. Most of us also have brains to understand that an AT missile can one shot even the heaviest tank if you expose its side or rear armor, or that enemy AA will most likely shoot down your old slow bomber which doesn't have any countermeasures, or that napalm strike will paint pant's of your infantrymen brown, or that your artillery needs ammunition or that 20 is more than 10.

Sure, you don't know all the tricks when you start your first match but you'll get there. There are great single player campaigns (both in Red Dragon and the previous titles) and there is also a chat window in the main menu full of people who can answer your questions and give tips. (At least when it's not full of Russians mocking Americans and Americans mocking Russians and Europeans mocking everyone.)

Single player offers a lot of practice opportunities. You can either play skirmish games and adjust the difficulty the way you want or once you think you are ready you can try single player campaigns. I found the campaigns challenging (=fun) even for a Wargame veteran, not to mention the amount of interesting tactical and strategic opportunities.

Addition of naval units was a big thing of Red Dragon so I guess I should say something of it. The naval units are often called unbalanced by the players and I guess they are slightly. It's also kind of unfortunate that the ships are only from few nations. I however wouldn't call it a total failure. Naval warfare is still fun and it makes the game more interesting in coastal maps as if you lose your naval presence you are in risk of amphibious landings in your rare. Ships' cannons are really powerful against ground units IF you can spot them, which the ships usually can't. On the other hand if ships move too close to shore pretty much any kind of tank platoons can make serious damage.

The deck system from Wargame Airland Battle is also here and better than ever. For those who are unfamiliar with the deck system, a deck is basically a pre-defined selection of units you choose for a battle. Decks are really fun to make because you can (and you should) get bonuses by adding restrictions and specializations. For example I really like my South Korean Marine deck, Canadian motorized deck or pre-1980s REDFOR tank decks.

The system has been rebalanced so all the deck types have become feasible. Especially airborne decks are really cool. Besides the five new countries there are coalitions which consist of several nations. The bonuses for coalitions are smaller but at least they get to keep their prototype units. My Commonwealth mechanized deck and South Korean-Japanese motorized deck just rock.

The maps in Wargame Red Dragon are also really cool with mountains, towns, deserts, forests, coastal areas, rivers and all of those potentially in a same map! This opens a ton of possibilities and makes almost any kind of deck playable in every map. We sure have come a long way from Wargame European Escalation's never-ending plains with some occasional woods.

As I said in my Wargame Airland Battle review, what makes Wargame really cool is the variety of everything that keeps the game fresh. Every player makes his own decks and chooses his own tactics. That's why every match is at least slightly different and you can never know what kind of BS enemy has in store for you.

The fun factor will also get multiplied by 10 if you have a friend in your team in a voice chat to coordinate with. That's where the possibilities of teamwork rocket through the roof.

Wargame Red Dragon is the ultimate peak of the evolution of Wargame franchise. It's probably the best think that has happened to RTS games for a few years and I love it just as much as I love the smell of napalm in mornings.

TL;DR: Play it. Play it. Play it.

It is unfortunate that in many cases, you’ll be zoomed all the way out to look at the map as a whole, or perhaps zooming in to watch a couple sectors. It’s seldom that you’ll have the luxury to view things up close like in the promo shots.

Much like Supreme Commander, you’ll spend the bulk of your time in Wargame looking at your units as a mass of icons. And this works, it makes sense. But darned if it’s not a waste of those lovingly crafted vehicle and structure models. But even at a distance, Red Dragon has a lot to offer visually. The user interface is utilitarian in the extreme, which is unsurprising given the density of information the game is asking you to parse and process constantly. I am, however, always a sucker for a fancy user interface, and can't help but wonder if they couldn't have done something slightly more appealing this tme around.

Wargame both is, and is not, frustratingly and even mind-achingly complex.

At its core, it’s actually built on some fairly simple and straightforward concepts: build a ‘deck’ of units, go into combat, kill the other guy's units. No production facilities, no reserch, just divide and conquer. Units in the game are broken down numerous ways: they're divided into 2 main factions, and 9 major categories. The factions are BLUEFOR, including the US, the UK, France, West Germany, Canada, Denmark, Sweden, Norway, ANZAC (Australia and New Zeland), South Korea and Japan. BLUEFOR is typically deemed simpler to play or even downright better than REDFOR from a balance perspective, but that's highly subjective. I came to personally prefer REDFOR. REDFOR, in its turn, is East Germany, the USSR, Poland, Czechoslovakia, China and North Korea. The Asian factions are new additions to this game, and are the origin of the game’s name (as should be painfully obvious).

Deck building is an art, and without guidance van be a formidable task. There are guides on Steam, and the game’s subreddit has a weekly deckbuilding thread, but for the uninitiated, simply deciding what units to bring with you can be an incredible challenge and point of contention with more veteran players.

Combat is unforgiving. Deeply so. Being caught out in the open, or by your units counter, is a sure, swift and humiliating defeat. And more than combined arms is necessary – the counterplay of these units goes several levels deep, often requiring multiple types of aircraft and anti-air in addition to artillery, tanks, and infantry combined. Naval warfare and naval units have their place in the game: mainly, via amphibious infantry carriers and other shallow water units. Larger vessels exist, but aren’t used particularly often in my experience. Deep sea units and combat feel gimmicky beside the much more polished and refined air/ground combat mechanics, into which riverine units fit much more neatly.


Wargame is amazing. I love it, I’m addicted to it. It has tons to learn and master, and mechanics that I can only describe as deeply satisfying. But its learning curve, the burden of knowledge that goes largely unsupported, is undeniably and unavoidably steep. With an afterthought tutorial, and so much opacity involved both in what units to bring into combat and in actual engagements with the enemy, Wargame is uncaring towards the plight of new players, an attitude often adopted by the game’s very community, which is at times shockingly virulent towards new players.

I recommend this game, but there are lot of disclaimers to note:

1. There is a STEEP learning curve to the game, and there isn't a good tutorial in-game.

2. While there are a few good guys who don't mind helping out a noob, the vast majority of the community will view you as prey to get an easy win. Proof? Now why do I recommend the game?

reviewText:
This. Is. A. Fantastic. Game.

HOW I GOT STARTED WITH WARGAME RED DRAGON
I am a die-hard Supreme Commander fanboy, and I was skeptical of this game. I had tried European Escalation and it really wasn't my jam, however my friend bought this for me (Thanks, Jack) and I decided I should give the series a second chance.

GAMEPLAY
The gameplay mechanics are, well, great. If you play a great deal of RTS's within a small area of time like me, then controls can get confusing, but that's just boling down to if left click or right click assigns orders. Through my time playing this, I've found that unit placement is far more important than numbers. Having one Stinger standing in the treeline of a forest is far more useful than two stingers in the open. Unit placement is also key, because the enemy gets points for destroying your stuff on the most common gamemode. One problem I have always had is anti-ship missiles versus ships, as the missiles would get destroyed and then my plane would get shot down. I am not sure if the range of the AA on most ships is intentional, but I feel like I should get that out there. There is also a counter to everything, and make sure you cover every type of potential attack in your deck, which I will talk about next.

DECKS
If you are a fan of Wargame long before Red Dragon came out, you can skip this section entirely as I want to share how decks work and how a deck with a blend of cheap/expensive units (versus all cheap / all expensive). Decks are a lot like unit designators. You design your custom deck (Or use a prebuilt one), and you have two options to start with. BLUFOR, or OPFOR. Within those choices, you have the option (But you don't have to) to pick a country within those two factions. Within THOSE choices, you can ( But you don't have to) specialize within that unit, which will restrict the use of some units, but unlock others and give you extra unlocking points towards infantry/armor/air/etc. Finally, you can restrict yourself to a time period to give you more activiation points, but you lose the avaliability of some units. I have never had to use this type of deck. Covering the blend of Cheap/Expensive units, if you have an army of crummy, cheap units, then your army will get destroyed quickly by the enemies (Presumably) superior force. If you have too many expensive units, then you will not be able to get enough units out to cover all your sides, and you will be flanked.

MULTIPLAYER
The multiplayer is fantastic. But I write that with a conditional tone. The multiplayer is some of the best you'll ever experience if you have teammates that know what they are doing and support each other. However this is only 40% of your random games. I don't have much else to say about multiplayer, except it is certainly a challenge no matter what sector you're holding down.

OVERVIEW
The whole bloody review was an overview. Great game.
9/10.

I realize that my review was a little pieced together and guide-ish, but read some other reviews and keep mine in mind and you'll see if you'll like this game or not.

reviewText:
I greatly anticipated this game for a long time, after falling deep in love with AirLand Battle. If you are a veteran RTS player, or never touched one in your life, or a military buff that has never even played a game, this game is really something for you.

However, I will warn you now, that there is a large learning curve in the multiplayer. To compete against experienced players takes a lot of learning, as the massive selection of units, maps, and mechanics makes it an enormous task. This does not mean you can not have fun learning though! (read on..)

In skirmish modes (Against the AI) You have the option to slow down and stop (as well as speed up) time to give you more time to give orders to your units

The deck mechanic is really what adds so much to this game. You can spend many hours (I have) browsing the armoury, analysing and comparing unit stats, adding them to your deck, checking out the amazing unit models, and then getting to take them to combat! With 1450 units in the game, there is an amazing feeling with finding that an understated unit is a beautiful performer - You can get very attached to them.

The devs have really taken what was excellent about the two previous games, and then piled on more. There is plenty in this game for you.

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon will certainly come off a dissapointment to most AirLand Battle players, and while it isn't terrible, there aren't many reasons I could think of to recommend this game over AirLand Battle, especially for its hefty pricetag.

To go into detail, let's look at what the game gets right. There is a huge roster expansion, with many new vehicles, factions, and maps. Sadly, most of these new units are reskins of existing ones, but this is true to life, so Eugen deserves some lee-way. The maps are massive and expansive. I am not sure if they are bigger than AirLand Battle, but it sure felt like it. Logistics is more important, as vehicles run out of fuel much quicker and the bigger maps also eat up more fuel. It is an interesting system that adds a dynamic to the game that we haven't seem previously, as going after supply vehicles will actually damage the enemy greatly.

Now let us talk about where it goes wrong. Oh, there are so, so many ways this game goes wrong. First and formost is that they screwed up the deck building system. Now, when you make a deck, there are only five open unit slots, where as previous games held all 10 open for use for any deck. The problem is that the game forces you to use specialized decks, but specialization is a bad idea. What if you happen to bring a specialized deck that is vulnerable to the enemy's deck type? Well, you're screwed. The five slots prevent you from making a well-rounded deck. I get they wanted people to have incentive for using specialized decks, but this was not the way to do it. They should provide postive reinforcement for choosing to specialize, like making the bonuses for specialized decks greater (and making their unit restrictions less harsh: many units that certain specializations exclude you from don't even fit into the opposing category, meaning it just removes units for no reason), not by removing stuff that made normal decks good.

Balance is all over the ♥♥♥♥ing place. AirLand Battle struck a nice balance, with only the jets being a little overpowered. Now that is flipped on its head. One SAM (or Redfor equivalent) can easily pummel a jet. Sure, anti-air availability has been cut, and so has their ammo, but now planes are weak as ♥♥♥♥ and they rarely even reach their traget. They are just a good way of wasting money. Infantry is also useless. Before, putting infantry in buildings was an effective way to ensure that area of the map was basically yours, unless your enemy used specific anti-infantry vehicles to counter. Infantry are now weaker. They die quicker, and their weapons are far less effective against heavy armor. They are, however, cheap. The worst thing is artillery. I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ went through Eugen's Systems combined heads when they thought of making artillery more destructive. Artillery is supposed to be a support tool used for bogging down and enemy and lowering their morale in preparation for a ground attack, but in Red Dragon they are an offensive tool that can snipe units from across the map and continuously pound just about anything (and I do mean anything) to death. Entrentched infantry? Dead meat. Top-teir armor? Be gone after 3 salvos. Even helicopters can get ruined by these things. It is such an abysmal decision and it ruins a game like this, where arguably balance is everything.

Then there are navies. actual, proper ship on ship warfare can be fun, but there really isn't much to it. Whoever has more ships wins. You can spam extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥, low-level ships, but nothing will get through their output of fire.

These changes completely ruin this game and remove any fun from it. It is replaced with frustration, as opponents cheekily snipe you from across the map (including the all-seeing AI) with artillery, amass fleets of ♥♥♥♥ teir boats and tear through everything you have, and make the airforce a complete waste of time and money.

I thought Red Dragon would be fun because of the new units and setting, but I just got a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, unbalanced version of AirLand Battle that does not do justice to its predecessor. ALB is more well-rounded and balanced, and it is altogether more fun. Don't be tricked by fanboys throwing heaps of praise on this game, and don't waste your money. By ALB or EE.

As a sidenote, there is ONE group of people I can recommend this game to. RD has the easiest and most fair AI of all the Wargame titles. That doesn't mean it is easy or fair, it just means it is actually ♥♥♥♥ing beatable. So if you are mostly a singleplayer type of guy, you should probably pick this up.

reviewText: Wargame: Red Dragon is an interesting take on the strategy genre. The game takes place through two screens: the map screen and the battle screen. The map screen takes a form similar to that of WW2 planning boards you always see in movies, and is quite novel if not effective. The battle screen is as one might expect: a bird's eye view of the battlefield(with the option to zoom in to an incredible range) but what is interesting is not the screen but the mechanics of battle. If you've ever played almost any other RTS then you'll know ammunition is not usually a feature of those games. However in Wargame: RD you must worry about logistics, you'll need to send in supply trucks to keep your tanks armed and your Helicopters filled with missles.\n\nThe only real failing point of this game is the lack of the proper tutorial. The entire game is summarisied in text screen tutorials which do little to explain the complex mechanics of war. The RTS afficandio will quickly pick up the tools of the trade but I fear that someone not familiar to the genre might not fare as well.

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon is one of the best tactical real time strategy games I have ever played. Compared to other RTS games it is a lot more tactical, requiring the use of tactics like countering enemy units, taking cover in buildings, hiding units in forests, co-ordinating artillery attacks, using air support and much more!

The game becomes sort of click spammy (which is where its more about spamming units rather than strategy, e.g. Airmech) when you raise the resource points too high. However there are some units that work well in large groups and others that work well alone, so you don't really need to click spam either way.

Time for a pro/con list!

PROS:
Features many units and nations, more than most RTS Games!
Play with AI or online
Great accuracy with unit design, unit names etc.
Plenty of maps for 1v1s or 4v4s
Naval combat. Use naval as a way to strike the land or to have sea battles!
Terrain affects gameplay. Trees can hide units, buildings can be used to hide in
Accuracy, ammunition, fuel and other interesting gameplay mechanics
Interesting debates on the main menu
DLC released for the game is free!CONS:
The units don't have much variety (gameplay-wise)
It's Peer to Peer so internet issues can be common
Can be quite boring without friends
Can get boring quite quickly
So overall, a great game that I recommend to any RTS lover!

8/10

One more thing - CANCEL THE CHRONO!

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon is one of the best tactical real time strategy games I have ever played. Compared to other RTS games it is a lot more tactical, requiring the use of tactics like countering enemy units, taking cover in buildings, hiding units in forests, co-ordinating artillery attacks, using air support and much more!

The game becomes sort of click spammy (which is where its more about spamming units rather than strategy, e.g. Airmech) when you raise the resource points too high. However there are some units that work well in large groups and others that work well alone, so you don't really need to click spam either way.

Time for a pro/con list!

PROS:
Features many units and nations, more than most RTS Games!
Play with AI or online
Great accuracy with unit design, unit names etc.
Plenty of maps for 1v1s or 4v4s
Naval combat. Use naval as a way to strike the land or to have sea battles!
Terrain affects gameplay. Trees can hide units, buildings can be used to hide in
Accuracy, ammunition, fuel and other interesting gameplay mechanics
Interesting debates on the main menu
DLC released for the game is free!CONS:
The units don't have much variety (gameplay-wise)
It's Peer to Peer so internet issues can be common
Can be quite boring without friends
Can get boring quite quickly
So overall, a great game that I recommend to any RTS lover!

8/10

One more thing - CANCEL THE CHRONO!

reviewText:
A good addition to the series but a few flaws hold it back from being the crowning achievement it could have been.

Depending on the map played, sometimes the craters that appear from heavy shelling will appear to exist in a layer of dirt that exists a few feet below the transparent ground that used to be there before.  Normally it isn't even noticable but if you zoom in a lot on areas that get heavily bombarded you will see problems.  This was not a problem in ALB and hopefully might get patched in the next major update.

The game is the first in the series to let you set up AI players to use your own custom-made decks, which means you can create target-practice decks or simulate historical or hypothetical engagements (well... sort of, heh).

The addition of new units really changes the gameplay mechanics, as enemy AA defenses will rely far less on easily-vulnerable radar guidance systems.  Also, although you get a few more units per card than in past titles, the maps are much larger and can really punish you for losing certain units.  These arguments are all illustrated best in the AH-64D Longbow, which is the US's endgame glass cannon capable of turning a match completely around... or being a large waste of points never to return (you get 1 or 2 per deck, period).

A very fun title which is also relevant enough to get denial-of-service attacks from the North Koreans on a monthly basis.  The game also automatically logs you into the chat room where you can see them taunt our capitalist way of life.

8.5/10

Right, so: I'm gonna forworn the reader that I'm not, like a lot of other reviewers might be, a long-term Wargame fan. In fact, this is my first Wargame-...erm, game, ever bought and played.

But played, I have.

I'd come into Wargame originally from RUSE: another game out of the Eugen box. As for RUSE, it served as a wonderful experience for me: I've sunk in hundreds of hours into it throughout a total of about three to four years. And especially for my version being an X-Box port purchased before I really had a gaming PC, me still playing RUSE on occasion to this day helps cement how wonderful it is.

So understandably, I came into Wargame: Red Dragon with high expectations of perhaps my favorite Strategy Games studio. I'd become legitimately hyped on the trailers, and I'd always wanted to try out European Escalation or AirLand Battle.

I'm not going to lie: this was a weird game to get into when it first game out. There were no in-game tutorials and no singleplayer, making the current lack of a dedicated tutorial mode (to my knowledge) a cubscout picknick in comparison. I had to teach myself how to manuever units through a private MP lobby, and that was a difficult task when I had no idea how complicated the controls in Wargame were.

There were thankfully at least a few good and decent guides out there, but for other Wargames of course: thankfully, since I purchased it, a number of Red Dragon guides have arrived both from Eugen and from the vast community of players.

To summarize getting into the game, it's difficult even today. It's a heavy difficult curb, but that's also what makes it wonderful: Red Dragon is AS REAL AS IT CAN GET, by all assumption. Playing Wargame is a legitimate way to learn a little more about how real warfare tactics, at least from the Cold War era, were like (to a limited extent, of course). Eugen put a lot of effort into making this game flow smoothly in terms of both difficulty placed on the computer and on the player's own abilities: while your computer is going along just fine with relatively impressive and immersive graphics, you're trying your damn best to keep up-to-speed in an MP game.

There's also a large amount of singplayer capability as well: the uniqueness that the deck system provides (perhaps my favorite piece of this whole game) not only allows for the common joke of players spending more time on deck/army building than on playing the game, but also allowing for players to have their own customized adventures and battles.

In addition, there are a decent number of singleplayer campaigns set during various points in the Cold War. These campaigns are decent in story and certainly immersive, and provide a really interesting challenge for the player. Of course, these aren't really the good meat of the game.

As for the multiplayer: it's really the main bit, though not required. I'd still recommend anyone buying Wargame to try out MP at least a few times per month to continually improve battlefield skill and preformance. It's honestly interesting to watch a deck go into combat, and to analyize how one could've preformed better and which parts of the deck went by the make or break" principle.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I am not a big time RTS player. The only RTS games I have played are the earlier AoE games, 1, 2 and a little bit of Mythology; so my review of this RTS game may not be framed in ways similar to others who may have considerably more RTS gaming experience. I also have really only played the Destruction multiplayer game mode and tend to only play with friends or play solo.

Wargame: Red Dragon is a fast paced RTS set during the Cold War. Players control individual units that they deploy from a pre-selected group of units called a 'Deck' that they can build (or share with friends!) based on nations belonging to NATO or the Warsaw Pact.

W:RD takes out the boring aspect of resource collection and keeps the action fast and intense; It is not easy to learn and very hard to master. After 144 hours I still have yet to beat the first campaign. (My perfectionist habits have something to do with that, but only a little bit).

Pros:
- Obvious learning curve (only a pro if you're into that sort of thing. I am).
- Intense, fast paced action.
- A lot of units and nations to choose from. Deck building actually got me interested in other nation's military hardware/history.
- Multiplayer is great with friends; ignore the overall community in the global chat. Frankly just turn that off.
- The AI on higher difficulties punishes you for stupid strategies.

Cons:
- Lack of tutorial content. (Lots of good stuff on YouTube if you don't have any friends to help you learn).
- Maps start to feel a tad boring/same with how many there are. This game could benefit from a lot more maps.
- Without your own server you can't host games larger than 4v4. (This game supports 10v10)
- Lack of simplified mod support. There are mods, but the support for them could be more streamlined for creators and users.

Notes: I'm sure a lot of people may talk about 'balance' and such but I have yet to fully experience the full potential of this game and different potential strategies so I cannot rightly speak about balance yet.

Favorite deck style: West Germany Mechanized.

This is a definite buy for me. Full price. Even better if you can get it on sale or in a huge Steam sale Wargame pack deal and get the older games, too. See how the series has changed between releases.

This is quite possibly my favorite game of all-time. The game is an RTS in the same sense as the latest C&C4 (No real Base-building) Except it doesn't arbitrarily limit the number of units you can have. Maps are gigantic, battles are huge, and there are some aspects of it that everyone just loves. That being said, there are a few limitations that might drive some away. I'll address them below.

-Large Map Replayability
-Wide variety of countries available
-Land, Air, and Sea combat
-Immense experimentation possible
-Challenging Campaigns
-Multiplayer battles (TO THE MAX)

Bad:
-Sea is kind of half-baked and does not work realistically
-Otomatic was never sold to Denmark (Hehe)
-NO GOOD TUTORIAL!!!!
I know a lot of people complain about this one, but to be honest there's really nothing there! The in-game tutorial explains what each value means, but it never really explains how to play the game well. Many people just come in without any knowledge whatsoever and pick units arbitrarily. It requires some pretty intensive effort from experienced players (Like myself) to actually help these new guys and give them a hand. There are plenty of resources available for them on steam, but it's not always obvious where to find these.
-Planes are unrealistic as well
-SPAAG ground range is arbitrarily set at 1050m (Except for otomatic which is 2100, down from 2275)
-Tank Range maxxes out at 2275M (for no real reason)
-Ships don't fire KE/AP Rounds!!! (like they do IRL!)

Overall, I absolutely adore this game. The dings I gave it above are things most regular players won't care about or really notice. If you like RTS, you couldn't go wrong with purchasing this game and having a blast. Please read the tutorials after you do, and check out a guide or two! If you're still confused, ask someone like me who knows how to play the game well for advice! We're happy to train you new guys!

reviewText:
A truly fantastic RTS, this game really should go up on the shelf alongside Command and Conquer, World and Conflict, and all of the other classic Real Time Strategy games out there. Wargame: Red Dragon is the refreshing 2014 installment and sequel to the 2013 Wargame: Airland Battle. Red Dragon is the third installment in the series and provides new features and choices for gameplay while retaining the best features of the Wargame: ALB. This time the Cold War moves from it's Theater of War in Northern Europe to the Pacific and Eastern Asia. Fans of the previous Wargames franchise as well as players new to the series will be really delited with this latest sequel as developer Eugen Systems debuts it's 2014 installment in the Wargames series. Oh Yeah, did I mention they added Naval Combat?!

Singleplayer:
For those of you who have played Wargames before, whetehr it be Wargame: European Escalation or Wargame: Airland Battle, you will know that the plot line for the franchise is set in a ficticious alternate historical timeline set in the late 1970's and well into the 1980's. Wargame: Red Dragon features four new campaign plot lines set during the cold war in Asia; each is set in a different time with a different faction. The reason there are four different campaigns is because of the fact that each campaign goes along with a difficulty setting: command the South Korean military forces in order to repel an overwhelming North Korean invasion force on Easy Difficulty. Try reigniting the Sino-Soviet border conflict as the Chinese on Medium Difficulty. Repel an immense offensive by the PLA of China in an attempt to reclaim Hong Kong as the British on Hard Difficulty. And for the finale, lead a conquest of the Japanese mainland before the American forces can arrive in order to support their comrades in distress as the Soviet Union on Very Hard difficulty. So, with all of these different campaigns the player is given more choice in how they go about tackling a situation then in most RTS campaigns which I found to be really enjoyable since the game conforms to your playing style. I think that the developers of this game did a great job in not just the way the game plays but also in the storyline in order to make it as realistic as possible but still balanced enough to fight a fair war. Choosing the late Cold War as a time to set an RTS is really interesting because weaponry and warfare are still balanced at this point between either the PACT faction or the allied NATO forces. The context of the setting takes place before the information era so weapons systems haven't quite yet reach a point a point where a drone strike can whipe out a unit of hostil forces with the push of a button from all the other side of the globe. This games storyline and multiplayer provides two different ideologically parted empires waging violent and destructive skirmishes across the globe. While Wargame: Red Dragon's campaign is a fantastic embodiement of these features and incorporating them into it's storyline, the only thing that bugged me a bit was how in the singleplayer storyline the conflicts didn't seem to have much connection to each other and should have been drawnout longer.

Multiplayer:
While the Wargame series is infamous for it's setting during the Cold War, the embodiement of these factors is better brought out through the multiplayer experience. Set on a number of maps throughout Asia (I presume) the multiplayer element feels the same and doesn't stray too much from Wargame: ALB with the exception of new Asia based factions and units added to the game. In terms of map diversity however, the game does feel a bit different in the details. The more traditional maps of the first two Wargame installments were set in European countryside towns with some Urban presence including buildings for infantry to duke it out in, but usually it would be forests and farms. Wargame: Red Dragon's maps are different both visually and aesthetically. Since the addition of naval warfare to the series, the maps in Wargame generally revolve around coastal areas with dense jungle and plots of rice farms. The forests have now generally been replaced by jungle. One of the latest items of the maps for this game I was excited about was the introduction of denser maps which means more urban areas and denser jungles which really allowed for the tank battles to take place further away then the infantry battles. The overall experience of Wargame multiplayer feels like it's gotten a refreshing new update and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a good pop-in and pop-out RTS.

reviewText:
(Had to wright this review AGAIN from scratch because steam didn't post and save it the last time so bear with me if something seems off or typos.)

This is an amazing strategy game and a MUST have for RTS fans. Has a high learning curve so don't expect any handholding.
PROS:

+ No Unit Limits. (I've had upwards of over 300 units on the field at one time this includes tanks/infantry/vehicles/helicopters, and jets not counting my allies or enemies units.)

+ Thousands of Different Units. (Though some are kind of reskins each unit has their own special role on the battle field.)

+ VERY Strategic. (Should I postion my infantry in the nearby town and have them take cover in the buildings below or just march a few thousand infantry in forest cover over that mountain and risk getting napalm bombed if spotted by a recon unit.........meh I'll just fire a few hundred artillary rounds at their base camp and try to get lucky.)

+ Cinimatic AND Functional. (Not often does a game manage to create so many cinimatic moments yet be fully about a functional playing experience)

+ Polished Land Combat. (Land combat is pretty much perfect in this game more on water combat later.)

+ Resource Management. (Your Frontline Base(FOB) comes with a set supply number. Pay close attention as this will be your life blood. Your resoures are split into 3 categories Ammo, Fuel, and Spare Parts. Managing to supply units far off will prove to be rather challenging but all the more fun. You have a limited number of units that can deliever supplies with their own varying strengths and weaknesses. Supply ships can be sunk, Cargo Caravans can be stolen/blown to hell, and supply choppers can be shot down so be careful with them in high conflict areas as they will be high priority targets for the enemy.)

+ Multiplayer. (Yay for some Nay for others more on that later)

+ Lots of Factions. (From Nato, to North Korea, to Russia and many more)


CONS:

- Water Units/Combat Sucks. (Red Dragon introduced water units into the Wargame franchise and it really shows. What lies before you is a lackluster experience. Water combat is clunky, ship pathing is wonky and besides the many other obscure reasons I'd rather fight a donkey. Ok lame jokes aside the new water units mainly ships with the occasional sea helicopter or jet are sorely under utilized as most players have just given up on water units and maps altogether because of said problems. Not to mention maps that have a heavy water and land mix screw over infantry that ride in vehicles as they can not travel across water and there are no ships that can ferry them across. The only way to get infantry around on a water/land map is if they're helicopter troops. Eugene has something going here but it really needs more work put into it.)

- Multiplayer. (1. If you expect to enjoy that glorious 10x10 multiplayer action BEWARE! As the game will kick you if your internet speeds are too slow. Honestly I've never played a multi match until the end because my internet speed  is such garbage. Thankfully the game has a great single player skirmish mode with a very competent AI where most players spend their time.  If you have pretty decent speeds this shouldn't be a problem though. 2. Because of said problems and a few other's finding a multi match may be a bit hard and even if you do the game will kick players for speeds or some may just leave for reasons causing you to be put in a situation where it's almost impossible to win a match.)

- No Resupplying of FOBs. (Ok some people are gonna say that's what's so good about the game or that I'm a noob and using too much or I'm not playing strategically or I should have just built more before the start of the game. While that may all be true at times it shouldn't be used as an excuse to cover up such a glaring fault. If this game sales itself as a realistic strategy I don't know how they justify real world bases actually getting supplied but not here. Though you can increase the amount of supplies a FOB has in a txt file in the directory, an ingame feature where you order a resupply for limited amount should have been added.)

- NO NEW MAPS! (There's been a lot of reasons given why Eugene hasn't added new maps such as they had to take time from the development to fix bugs and exploits instead . But now they're working on their new game AOA which is taking up all their manpower. What has constantly been requested is a Map Editor or some sort of tools where we the community can make our own maps. The excuses for this not being a thing have been varying and confusing from Eugene not owning the engine the game is made with too maps being too complicated for tools to recreate or something along those lines. Really we have the original maps but having something new to play on would be GREAT at this point)

- No Modding Support. (Sure there are a few mods here and there but they're almost unheard of. Some people who have played the game for a long time still don't know their are mods and that mods could even be made for this game. So far there are a fair bit of skins and a few other mods like sandbox but nothing MAJOR grandbreaking like you know.......NEW ♥♥♥♥ING MAPS!!! When Eugene returns to the series they need to seriously think about making the franchise moddable)




tl;dr: The game looks good, plays good on land, has ALOT of stuff and resource management but water stuff sucks, multiplayer is jacked for most, NO NEW MAPS and no mod support.


Final Rating: 7.5/10  Updated Rating(5/4/2016): 8.5/10
