reviewText:
This is a lengthy review, so if you would rather see the pros and cons, just skip to the bottom.

For those new to the series, Wargame: Red Dragon is the 3rd game in the series. It differs from the first two in that the battles and campaigns take place in Asia, mostly the Korean peninsula, instead of Central and Western Europe. It also differs from the first two in that naval combat is present in this game, but more on that below. Now onto the review.

Graphics and Sound
This is first thing most people see when watching the trailer. They don't dissapoint. All three games in the series have amazing graphics, and Red Dragon is no exception. Watch in amazement as dozens of rockets, shells, and rounds pound the enemy and the ground. Craters are left, forest burned down, and entire neighbourhoods destroyed as you fight for control of the strategic sectors scattered around the map. Sounds are also well done. Not only will you see that 500 pound bomb hit the ground, you'll hear it loud and clear. Some explosions can even be heared clear across the map!

Campaigns and Skirmish Mode
Singleplayer consists of two game modes: campaigns and skirmish mode. Skirmish mode has stayed the same from the previous games. Not much to say about it, pick your army deck, your enemy, and your map and fight it out. The campaigns are where things have changed. There are currently five campaigns:  Busan Pocket, Bear vs. Dragon, Pearl of the Orient, Climb Mount Narodnaia, and 2nd Korean War(DLC). So far I've tired Bear vs. Dragon and Pearl of the Orient, which are pretty challenging. I've more or less played through Busan Pocket and 2nd Korean War, each of which play well and are pretty balanced.

The main addition to the campaigns is the seperation of units. Unlike Wargame: AirLand Battle where each division had reccon units, tanks, planes, ect., Red Dragon seperates units into armored divisions, infantry divisions and squadrons. I found this an interesting addition, and I think it adds to the game. You'll now have to decide who gets air support, who gets armored units and even who gets proper supply lines. There are drawbacks however. I noticed that there are little or no random events and the strategic options such as commando raids and air reccon arn't present either. While they didn't really affect the campaign overall, I did miss the air reccon.

Naval Battles and Gameplay
For my last trick, I'll talk about the long awaited naval battles! From what I gathered, these were a long awaited addition to the game. Let me just say that if your buying this on account of the naval battles, don't. To be honest, they're harder than the ground battles, and not really in a fun way. If you play as NATO, you'll find yourself massing your fleet of two destroyers and seven PT boats together to avoid the rain of anti-ship missels being thrown at you by the Soviet-Chinease fleet, which is made up of one or two large destroyers, and dozens of light ships. I suppose it could just be me(I didn't really try to conquer the sectors to get more points), but it feels unbalanced. It also felt unrealistic because the larger ships can't fire over obstacles or even very far. If your like me, and your playing this more for the land battles, then you'll enjoy it. The navel aspect means some vehicles can cross rivers, and the PT boats are fun to use on the smaller rivers. Reinforcements can also come by sea in landing craft.

One thing I did notice from all this is the AI has been downgraded a bit from AirLand Battle. I find that the AI is constantly massing units together and rushing me. This usually ends in 90% of the AI's army being destroyed at bridges or other choke points. It did ambush me a few times when I was on the offensive, but overall it seems dumber. Another slightly annoying thing is that when your making custom decks, your now limmited to a certain amount of transports. So if I want to build an airborne army consisting of Huey helicopters, I can only select five units before I have use a different helicopter. Again, It's not a game breaker, but it is a little annoying. I suppose it does challenge you, though, as you'll have to decide who will get the best transports.

So overall, here's what I see:

Pros:
Excellent graphics
Great Sounds
Good campaigns
Lots of new units and new nations
F-86 Sabres with rocket pods!
New naval combat units for you to rule the coastal maps with

Cons
New naval battles a little out of wack
AI seems a little dumber
Deck building a little more complicated
No random events or strategic options

Overall, I've really enjoyed this game, and despite it's few problems, I still reccomend it. It's a good addition to the series and it is a lot of fun. If your on the fence, or still want it for the naval combat, then I'd wait untill it's on sale.

reviewText:
Lots of fun. It takes a little time and breaking the mold of normal rts games.

Normal rts strategy games. Get the most powerful unit(s) and spam to win right?
Not so much with this game. There are over 1500 different units in this game, ranging from infantry, APC's, trucks, supply trucks, tanks, mobile tank hunters, atgm's, helicopters, mobile sam rocket launchers, airplanes, boats, artillery and more. Every unit has a very specific function, whether it is dedicated anti air, or robust like infantry. There is a lot to learn about this game, but the community is helpful to new players learning, and everyone is always ready for a new challenge.
Going back to earlier, spam to win. That doesn't work in this game because you need to balance quality with quantity. You normally have to defend many zones, and if you have your best troops in the center (and hoping they dont die) you have nothing to defend against the 30 squads of rangers creeping through the forest, or many you spent your points more wisely, and you have your own militias to counter, but they have better troops. You need to balance your troops and with a little luck, you may survive the charge.
